answer_html: \(M=\lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)\) and this last limit diverges. So \(M\) diverges. Therefore, the given series diverges by the integral test.
answer_latex:
$M=\lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)$  and this last limit diverges. So $M$ diverges. Therefore,
the given series diverges by the integral test.
hints_html:
Which series test works well for series involving logarithmic terms?

The integral test is a good choice to use here.

To evaluate the related integral, try the substitution \(\displaystyle u = \ln\ln x\). This can also be done by doing two substitutions that look like \(\displaystyle u = \ln x\).
hints_latex: Which series test works well for series involving logarithmic terms?
The integral test is a good choice to use here.

To evaluate the related integral, try the substitution
$\displaystyle u = \ln\ln x$. This can also be done by doing two
substitutions that look like $\displaystyle u = \ln x$.
hints_raw:
Which series test works well for series involving logarithmic terms?
The integral test is a good choice to use here.
To evaluate the related integral, try the substitution <math> \displaystyle u = \ln\ln x </math>. This can also be done by doing two substitutions that look like <math> \displaystyle u = \ln x </math>.
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the terms of the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all \(k \ge 3\), the lower bound of the sum. Let

\[\begin{aligned} M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.\end{aligned}\]

By the integral test, if \(M\) converges (or diverges), then so too does the series. To evaluate the integral \(M\), we use a change of variable. We let \(u = \ln(\ln(x))\). Under this change of variable, we have via the chain rule

\[\begin{aligned} u = \ln(\ln(x)) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x\ln(x)}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

We rewrite \(M\) using our change of variable:

\[\begin{aligned} M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{du}{u} \\ &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(u)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\ &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)\end{aligned}\]

and this last limit diverges. So \(M\) diverges. Therefore, the given series diverges by the integral test.

We proceed similarly to solution 1 except we alter the approach to the integral. For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the terms of the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all \(k \ge 3\), the lower bound of the sum. Let

\[\begin{aligned} M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.\end{aligned}\]

By the integral test, if \(M\) converges (or diverges), then so too does the series. To evaluate the integral\(M\), we use a change of variable. We let \(u = \ln(x)\). Under this change of variable, we have

\[\begin{aligned} u = \ln(x) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

We rewrite \(M\) using our change of variable:

\[\begin{aligned} M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(3)}^{\ln b}\frac{du}{u\ln u}\end{aligned}\]

Now we do another substitution. We let \(w = \ln(u)\). Under this change of variable, we have via the chain rule

\[\begin{aligned} w = \ln(u) \quad \rightarrow \quad dw = \frac{1}{u}\,du.\end{aligned}\]

We rewrite \(M\) using our change of variable:

\[\begin{aligned} M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{dw}{w} \\ &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(w)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\ &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)\end{aligned}\]

and this last limit diverges. So \(M\) diverges. Therefore, the given series diverges by the integral test.
sols_latex:
For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the terms of
the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all $k \ge 3$, the
lower bound of the sum. Let

\begin{align*}
M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.
\end{align*}
By the integral test, if $M$ converges (or diverges), then so too does
the series. To evaluate the integral $M$, we use a change of variable.
We let $u = \ln(\ln(x))$. Under this change of variable, we have via the
chain rule

\begin{align*}
u = \ln(\ln(x)) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x\ln(x)}\,dx.
\end{align*}
We rewrite $M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{du}{u} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(u)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)
\end{align*} and this last limit diverges. So $M$ diverges. Therefore,
the given series diverges by the integral test.

We proceed similarly to solution 1 except we alter the approach to the
integral. For this series, we apply the integral test. Notice that the
terms of the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all
$k \ge 3$, the lower bound of the sum. Let

\begin{align*}
M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.
\end{align*}
By the integral test, if $M$ converges (or diverges), then so too does
the series. To evaluate the integral$M$, we use a change of variable. We
let $u = \ln(x)$. Under this change of variable, we have

\begin{align*}
u = \ln(x) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx.
\end{align*} We rewrite
$M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(3)}^{\ln b}\frac{du}{u\ln u}
\end{align*} Now we do another substitution. We let $w = \ln(u)$. Under
this change of variable, we have via the chain rule

\begin{align*}
w = \ln(u) \quad \rightarrow \quad dw = \frac{1}{u}\,du.
\end{align*} We rewrite
$M$ using our change of variable:

\begin{align*}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{dw}{w} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(w)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)
\end{align*} and this last limit diverges. So $M$ diverges. Therefore,
the given series diverges by the integral test.
sols_raw:
For this series, we apply the <b>integral test</b>. Notice that the terms of the sum are positive, decreasing and continuous for all <math>k \ge 3</math>, the lower bound of the sum.  Let
:<math>
M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.
</math>
By the integral test, if <math>M</math> converges (or diverges), then so too does the series. To evaluate the integral <math>M</math>, we use a <b>change of variable</b>. We let <math>u = \ln(\ln(x))</math>. Under this change of variable, we have via the chain rule
:<math>u = \ln(\ln(x)) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x\ln(x)}\,dx</math>.
We rewrite <math>M</math> using our change of variable:
:<math>
\begin{align}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{du}{u} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(u)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)
\end{align}
</math>
and this last limit diverges. So <math>M</math> diverges. <font style="color:blue;">Therefore, the given series diverges by the integral test</font>.

:<math>
M = \int_{3}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))} = \lim_{b \to \infty}\int_{3}^{b}\frac{dx}{x\ln(x)\ln(\ln(x))}.
</math>
By the integral test, if <math>M</math> converges (or diverges), then so too does the series. To evaluate the integral<math>M</math>, we use a <b>change of variable</b>. We let <math>u = \ln(x)</math>. Under this change of variable, we have
:<math>u = \ln(x) \quad \rightarrow \quad du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx</math>.
We rewrite <math>M</math> using our change of variable:
:<math>
\begin{align}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(3)}^{\ln b}\frac{du}{u\ln u}
\end{align}
</math>
Now we do another substitution. We let <math>w = \ln(u)</math>. Under this change of variable, we have via the chain rule
:<math>w = \ln(u) \quad \rightarrow \quad dw = \frac{1}{u}\,du</math>.
We rewrite <math>M</math> using our change of variable:
:<math>
\begin{align}
M &= \lim_{b \to\infty}\int_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\frac{dw}{w} \\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln(w)\Big\vert_{\ln(\ln(3))}^{\ln\ln b}\\
&= \lim_{b \to\infty}\ln\ln\ln b - \ln\ln\ln (3)
\end{align}
</math>
and this last limit diverges. So <math>M</math> diverges. <font style="color:blue;">Therefore, the given series diverges by the integral test</font>.
statement_html:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

(c)

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k = 3}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k\ln(k)\ln(\ln(k))}\,.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

'''(c)'''
:<math>
\sum_{k = 3}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k\ln(k)\ln(\ln(k))}\,.
</math>
